From Clovis to Hobbs, and everywhere in between and beyond, and in every aspect of community, business, government, and life, Black New Mexicans are a critical part of the fabric that makes our state strong, beautiful, and thriving.
New Mexico, and the third district, have a strong and proud legacy of Black history and achievement that continues today and that we celebrate year-round.

Blackdom was a thriving farming community, but drought in the 1920s impacted communities throughout Southeastern NM, and the members of Blackdom had to leave. Many families settled throughout other parts of the state, and Frank Boyer went on to establish the town of Vado, NM.

In the late 1800s, Frank Boyer traveled by foot from Georgia to the New Mexican Territory to make a better life for his family, founding a community called Blackdom in the Pecos Valley, near Roswell, New Mexico in 1908.

During the Civil War, between 3,000 and 4,000 African American soldiers ‚Äî known as the Buffalo Soldiers ‚Äî served in New Mexico, not just protecting New Mexicans but also building critical infrastructure.

The Black community in New Mexico has a rich history and legacy dating back 500 years, to 1539, starting with Estevanico, a Spanish Moor from North Africa who came to the land that is now New Mexico looking for gold.

In February, we celebrate Black History Month, and the contributions of the Black community across New Mexico and our nation. 

Black History is New Mexican History. üßµ
